Precalculus_Level 4_4.json.correct_solution:
Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.$  Note that
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 5 & -8 \\ 2 & -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 2 \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} -  \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 2 \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Thus, let
\[\mathbf{B} = \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{I} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -4 \\ 1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\mathbf{B}^2 = \mathbf{0},$ and $\mathbf{A} = \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I},$ so by the Binomial Theorem,
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^{2016} &= (\mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I})^{2016} \\
&= \mathbf{B}^{2016} + \binom{2016}{1} \mathbf{B}^{2015} + \binom{2016}{2} \mathbf{B}^{2014} + \dots + \binom{2016}{2014} \mathbf{B}^2 + \binom{2016}{2015} \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I} \\
&= 2016 \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I} \\
&= 2016 \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -4 \\ 1 & -2 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4033 & -8064 \\ 2016 & -4031 \end{pmatrix}}.
\end{align*}Note: We can expand $(\mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I})^{2016}$ using the Binomial Theorem because the matrices $\mathbf{B}$ and $\mathbf{I}$ commute, i.e. $\mathbf{B} \mathbf{I} = \mathbf{I} \mathbf{B}.$  In general, expanding a power of $\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}$ is difficult.  For example,
\[(\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B})^2 = \mathbf{A}^2 + \mathbf{A} \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{B} \mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}^2,\]and without knowing more about $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{B},$ this cannot be simplified.

generated_solutions.gemini-1.5-pro:
```python
Step 1:
We try to diagonalize the matrix.
The characteristic polynomial of the matrix  \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} is 
\[\begin{vmatrix} 3-\lambda & -4 \\ 1 & -1-\lambda \end{vmatrix} = (3-\lambda)(-1-\lambda) - (-4)(1) = \lambda^2 -2\lambda +1 = (\lambda - 1)^2.\]
Step 2:
Thus, the eigenvalue $\lambda = 1$ has multiplicity 2.
We find an eigenvector for $\lambda = 1$:
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 - 1 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 - 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us the system of equations
\begin{align*}
2x - 4y &= 0, \\
x - 2y &= 0.
\end{align*}These equations are redundant, so $x = 2y.$  Thus, any nonzero multiple of $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is an eigenvector.
Step 3:
Since the eigenspace has dimension 1, the matrix is not diagonalizable.  We can write
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & a \\ 1 & b \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & a \\ 1 & b \end{pmatrix}^{-1}\]for some $a$ and $b.$  Then
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 & a \\ 1 & b \end{pmatrix}^{-1} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & a \\ 1 & b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]We can take $a = -2$ and $b = 0,$ so
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}^{-1} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Step 4:
Then
\begin{align*}
\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{2016} &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}^{-1} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}^{-1} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}^{-1} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{2016} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}^{-1} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2016 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -\frac{1}{2} & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2017 & -4030 \\ 1 & -2015 \end{pmatrix}}.
\end{align*}
Final answer:
\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 2017 & -4030 \\ 1 & -2015 \end{pmatrix}}
```
